artist: Artist: Thomas Zipp; Printer: Thumbprint Editions, London; Publisher: Paragon Press, London
description: 3/4 black and white portrait of a figure in a suit and tie superimposed with image of loose curvilinear black scribbles; "mens agitat molem" at top center in white with several letters mirrored; image bordered in green; Lender's archive #167
inscription:
Titled in pencil, LL: mens agitat molem
Inscribed in pencil, verso: 14
markings:
Numbered in pencil, verso: 13/42
Watermark: sommerset/england
medium: Photo-etching and aquatint printed in black and green
provenance: William P. Kosmas, London, England (d. 2017); Estate of William P. Kosmas, Minneapolis; given to MIA, 2018.
signed: Signed and dated, in pencil, LR: Thomas Zipp 06
text: In the prints from the “Black Dada” portfolio (Mia 2018.123.4.1-.14), German artist and musician Thomas Zipp uses photomontage to alter a photograph of Otto Hahn, a German scientist whose research led to the development of the atomic bomb. For the final print in the portfolio, Zipp portrays Hahn partially shrouded by fragments of text from the Aeneid, Virgil’s ancient epic poem concerning the founding of Rome by Aeneus, whose fate was governed both by free will and destiny. The image symbolizes the eclipsing of Hahn’s perceived scientific progress by unanticipated outcomes and the inevitable deterioration of society.
title: mens agitat molem
